resources.string: The Cracow Gate which is the part of City Hall was built in 14th century. In XV or XVI century the gate was expanded by one storey. In 1842 the city hall connected to the gate was built and since then it has been the seat of the city authorities.

In this place during the times of Kazimierz Wielki (king of Poland) there was a wooden stronghold. It was destroyed during fire in 1791. In 1843 there were built a new neoclassical palace on the lower parts of the castle walls. Today it is the seat of the Wieluń district authorities.

On August 31, 2013, the monument "Eternal Love" by Wojciech Siudmak was unveiled. The work shows two faces: a woman and a man like two planets suspended in space, which connect in their orbits to form the infinity sign. The monument was unveiled on the eve of the 74th anniversary of the outbreak of World War II.
Park Miejski im. Żwirki i Wigury
Church dedicated to Saint Michael the Archangel. One of the first Wielun templates, build around 13-14th centuries. It was destroyed during Word War II in the spring of 1940.

The Wieluń fortifications were built after the city fire in 1335, gradually replacing the older wooden and earth fortifications. Wieluń\'s defensive walls were approximately 1,200-1,300 meters long and covered an area of approximately 12 ha. The two main streets of the city converged there, forming a spindle with a market square in the middle. The walls were additionally surrounded by a moat.
City Park named Zwirki i Wigury
The museum is located in the former convent of the Bernardine nuns. Has various archaeological, historical and ethnographic collections.

The cinema was built in 1959-1962. There was a space for 578 people. In the 90’s the cinema stopped operating. A general renovation was carried out in 2010, and in October 2017, the cinema reopened.
City Park named after Mieczysław Kaluza
The park is located on the border of the city. Within it there is a botanical garden, a city stadium, a skate park, two football fields, a playground and a restaurant.
